Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 41073  
December 2007 
 
 
 
 
 
Lao People’s Democratic Republic:  
Preparing the Na Bong–Udon Thani Power 
Transmission Project 
(Financed by the Japan Special Fund) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 31 October 2007) 
 
Currency Unit –  kip (KN) 
KN1.00 =  $0.000104 
$1.00 =  KN9,607.78 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DEPD  –  Department of Energy Promotion and Development 
  DOE  –  Department of Energy 
  EdL  –  Electricité du Laos 
  EGAT  –  Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand 
  GMS  –  Greater Mekong Subregion 
  IEE  –  initial environmental examination 
  kV  –  kilovolt 
  Lao PDR  –  Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
  MEM  –  Ministry of Energy and Mines 
  MFF  –  multitranche financing facility 
  MW  –  megawatt 
  O&M  –  operation and maintenance 
  PPA  –  power purchase agreement 
  PPTA  –  project preparatory technical assistance 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Energy 
Subsector  –  Transmission and distribution 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth; regional cooperation  
Subthemes  –  Fostering physical infrastructure development; cross-
border infrastructure 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
Vice President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2 
Director General  A. Thapan, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Director  J. Cooney, Infrastructure Division, SERD 
   
Team leader  X. Humbert, Senior Energy Specialist, SERD 
Team members  E. Baardsen, Senior Infrastructure Specialist, SERD 
  Y. L. Feng, Principal Environment Specialist, SERD 
  M. Huddleston, Senior Social Development Specialist, SERD 
  P. Perera, Energy Specialist, SERD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) requested the 
Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) assistance1 to prepare the proposed Na Bong–Udon Thani 
Power Transmission Project for possible ADB financing. Preliminary fact-finding was undertaken 
during 27–31 August 2007, and the project’s concept clearance was obtained on 31 October 
2007. A subsequent mission fielded during 3–5 October 2007 reached an understanding with 
the Government on the objectives, scope, cost estimates, financing plan, and implementation 
arrangements  for  this  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA).  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Lao PDR is among the poorest countries in Asia with a gross domestic product per 
capita of $490 in 2005. The country has significant hydropower potential, estimated at about 
18,000 megawatts (MW), but only 663 MW has been harnessed so far. Thirty-three potential 
hydropower sites have been evaluated for development, and 11 projects with a total capacity of 
4,000  MW  are  expected  to  be  developed  in  the  next  15  years.  Realizing  the  country’s 
hydroelectric power potential is challenging due to domestic resource constraints on financing 
its  development.  Recognizing  the  need  to  attract  financing,  the  Government  is  strongly 
promoting private sector involvement; as such, most of the future projects were developed by 
independent power producers under concession agreements with the Government. Due to a 
fairly low domestic power demand and a rapidly growing power demand in other parts of 
Southeast Asia, most of the country’s hydropower is destined for export, which provides an 
opportunity to generate much-needed foreign currency revenues to the Government. These 
revenues will enable investments in rural electrification as well as in other social development 
and poverty reduction programs. Lao PDR’s export of hydropower also benefits other Southeast 
Asian  countries  like  Thailand  and  Viet  Nam  by  providing  economically  efficient  and  
climate-friendly power sources as compared to more expensive thermal power generation.  
 
3.  The Country Strategy and Program for Lao PDR has recognized the importance of 
developing its hydropower for export to generate foreign currency income through royalties, 
taxes, and dividends to the Government, which will in turn contribute to the country’s broader 
social  and  economic  development.  In  addition,  the  Regional  Country  Strategy  Program  
(2007–2009) for the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS)2 focuses on (i) strengthening physical 
infrastructure for cross-border connectivity, and (ii) integrating national markets for promoting 
economic  efficiency  and  private  sector  development.  The  GMS’s  power  market  is  moving 
toward  effective  regional  cooperation,  and  Lao  PDR  is  one  of  the  pioneering  countries  in 
bilateral power trade in accordance with the GMS’s Inter-Governmental Agreement on Regional 
Power Trade. The governments of Lao PDR and Thailand signed a framework agreement to 
trade power that provides power sale arrangements of up to 5,000 MW by 2015.  
 
4.  The proposed project will consist of two components: (i) acquisition by Electricité du 
Laos (EdL) from the Nam Ngum 2 project developer of the 27 kilometer (km)-long 500 kilovolt 
(kV) transmission line from Na Bong substation to the Thailand border, and (ii) construction of 
the 500/230 kV Na Bong substation. The transmission line and substation will be used as a 
common transmission facility to evacuate power from the Nam Ngum 2, Nam Ngum 3, Nam 
Theun 1, and Nam Ngiep 1 hydropower projects, which have a total capacity of over 1,800 MW. 
The  facility  will  be  owned  by  EdL  and  will  be  operated  and  maintained  by  a  proposed  
                                                 
1  The technical assistance (TA) first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 27 September 2007. 
2  ADB 2006. Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program Update (2007-2009): Greater Mekong Subregion. Manila.

2   
EGAT–EdL  joint  venture.  Each  hydropower  project  will  construct  a  dedicated  power 
transmission line to the Na Bong substation. The 500 kV transmission line is being financed and 
constructed by the Nam Ngum 2 developer by 2010 at 230 kV to evacuate power from the Nam 
Ngum 2 project to Thailand.  
 
5.  By mid-2012, the Na Bong substation is required to evacuate power from the Nam Ngum 
3 and Nam Theun 1 hydropower projects. The transmission line from Na Bong to the Thailand 
border will be connected to the substation, and its operating voltage will be upgraded to 500 kV. 
The Nam Ngiep 1 hydropower project, scheduled to begin commercial operation in January 
2014, will also be connected to the substation. As the substation and transmission line will be 
used as a common transmission facility to serve four hydropower projects, the Nam Ngum 2 
project’s concession agreement provided an option to the Government of buying back the 
transmission line at cost. The Government intends to finance the substation’s construction and 
the transmission line’s acquisition through the proposed project.  
 
6.  The proposed project is expected to be financed using ADB’s ordinary capital resources, 
and the corresponding loan’s debt service must be fully covered by the additional foreign 
currency revenues to be earned through wheeling charges, i.e., use of transmission charges. 
The loan will be structured as a multitranche financing facility (MFF) with two tranches. The first 
tranche will be used to finance the substation, with a contract award expected in mid-2009. The 
second tranche will be earmarked for the acquisition, i.e., refinancing, of the transmission line. It 
is envisaged that the refinancing will take place in 2012 when the substation is commissioned 
and the Nam Ngum 3 and Nam Theun 1 hydropower projects are ready to use the transmission 
line as a common transmission facility during their testing and commissioning period. The 
transmission line’s ongoing construction cost, buyout formula, and fairness of value will be 
determined during the PPTA’s course. The transmission line’s actual refinancing cost will be 
determined at the time the Government exercises its right to buy out the private investor and will 
be at a price not more than fair value, including the depreciation cost deduction. The terms and 
conditions of the second tranche’s loan will be negotiated with the Government separately upon 
completion of full appraisal. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the PPTA will be to promote the economic growth of the country and 
region by helping Lao PDR to develop its hydroelectric power resource in an environmentally 
and socially sustainable manner. It will also promote power trade in the GMS.  
 
8.  The outcome of the PPTA will be to formulate the proposed project’s financing program, 
using the MFF and preparing two loans that are structured and scheduled to suit the commercial 
operation schedule of the four hydropower developers. PPTA consultants will also prepare the 
legal documents for the subsequent operation of the common transmission facility provided 
through the proposed project and assist the Government in negotiating agreements with EGAT 
based on these documents. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The  PPTA  will  review  the  technical  design  of  the  Na  Bong  substation  and  the 
transmission line to assess their ability to transmit power reliably from all four hydropower plants 
by considering each power plant’s operating characteristics. PPTA consultants will undertake 
due diligence on the (i) cost estimates of the transmission line being built by the Nam Ngum 2

3
developer, including equipment and materials, and determine the cost of the section from Na 
Bong to the Thailand border; (ii) the implementation schedule for timely completion of the 
transmission line and substation to evacuate power from the associated hydropower projects; 
(iii) operation and maintenance (O&M) arrangements of EdL and EGAT for the transmission line 
and substation; and (iv) technical specifications of the substation and its compatibility with the 
EGAT and EdL power transmission systems. The PPTA will also review the bidding documents 
prepared by EGAT for the procurement of the substation on turnkey basis and assist EdL in the 
procurement  process,  including  bid  evaluation,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
10.  By undertaking an economic analysis in accordance with ADB guidelines, the economic 
benefits to Lao PDR and Thailand due to power trading will be identified, and the economic 
rationale for the Government’s investment in the common transmission facility will be justified. 
The PPTA will undertake a financial analysis from EdL’s point of view and will recommend the 
overall level of wheeling charges and a methodology for allocating them to the four hydropower 
projects by taking into account the construction costs, O&M costs, financing costs including 
interest during construction, and the timing of the projects’ commercial operation. The detailed 
cost estimates for both components will be prepared in accordance with ADB guidelines on 
identifying local and foreign costs, taxes, interest during construction, and price and physical 
contingencies.  The  PPTA  will  analyze  the  financial  implications  to  EdL’s  overall  financial 
performance,  due  to  its  ownership  of  the  common  transmission  facility,  and  update  EdL’s 
financial projections, which were prepared under earlier ADB technical assistance.3 
 
11.  The PPTA will undertake due diligence of the contractual and legal aspects associated 
with the transmission line’s financing by the Nam Ngum 2 developer and the transfer of its 
ownership to EdL, including the preparation of legal documents for the transfer. With respect to 
the hydropower companies’ power purchase agreement (PPA) obligations, the PPTA will also 
undertake due diligence of additional commercial risks for EdL due to its ownership of the 
transmission line and propose suitable mechanisms to mitigate these risks. These mechanisms 
will  include  recommendations  on  institutional  arrangements  for  the  common  transmission 
facility’s ownership, O&M agreements for the facility with EGAT, and contractual obligations on 
the transmission line’s reliability. The PPTA will prepare legal documents for the payment of 
wheeling charges by the hydropower developers to EdL, consistent with the PPA and the 
contractual  agreements.  Contractual  and  legal  mechanisms  will  be  proposed  for  
ring-fencing  the  wheeling  charges  to  have  first  priority  for  debt  service,  including  the 
establishment of an escrow account for debt service.  
 
12.  In accordance with ADB policies and guidelines on environmental assessments, the 
PPTA will review the initial environmental examination (IEE) and summary IEE prepared by the 
Nam Ngum 2 developer for the transmission line and will prepare the IEE for the Na Bong 
substation. The study shall cover both components’ areas, taking into account the likely impacts 
associated  with  their  locations,  designs,  and  construction  activities,  and  will  recommend 
improvements to the IEE for the transmission line if any inconsistencies with relevant ADB 
policies exist. Special attention will be paid to the proposed project’s proximity and anticipated 
impacts to culturally- and ecologically-protected areas as well as the transmission line’s Mekong 
River crossing. The PPTA will also undertake environmental due diligence on the environmental 
safeguard requirements and performance of the transmission line’s Thailand portion to identify 
inconsistencies with national safeguard requirements, recommend solutions or action plans to 
                                                 
3  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Preparing the Greater Mekong 
Subregion Northern Power Transmission Project. Manila. (TA 4816-LAO).

4   
address these irregularities, and summarize the results into the IEE and summary IEE.  
 
13.  In accordance with ADB’s relevant policies and guidelines, the PPTA will prepare a 
sample-based social impact assessment of the proposed project and its associated facilities 
(i.e.,  the  four  transmission  lines  connecting  to  Na  Bong  substation)  to  provide  adequate 
information  including  any  involuntary  resettlement  impacts  and  potential  impacts  on  ethnic 
minority  groups.  If  there  are  any  impacts  on  indigenous  peoples,  the  PPTA  will  provide 
mitigation  measures/affirmative  activities  to  ensure  that  they  are  safeguarded  during  the 
construction and project implementation period. The PPTA will undertake due diligence of the 
resettlement plan and its implementation for the transmission line and prepare a resettlement 
plan, including any ethnic minority-specific actions for the substation if social impacts result that 
will trigger ADB’s social safeguard policies.4 The PPTA will also conduct due diligence on the 
Thailand  portion  of  the  transmission  line  to  identify  inconsistencies  with  national  social 
safeguard requirements, recommend solutions or action plans to address these irregularities, 
and summarize the results into the social impact assessment report. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The PPTA’s total cost is estimated at $910,000 equivalent, comprising $760,000 in 
foreign currency and $150,000 equivalent in local currency. ADB will finance $760,000. The 
PPTA  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  through  the  Japan  Special  Fund,  funded  by  the 
Government  of  Japan.  The  Government  of  Lao  PDR  will  finance  the  remaining  $150,000 
equivalent of local currency cost through in-kind contributions. These contributions include office 
accommodation and facilities, counterpart staff, data, and other information needed for the 
PPTA. Detailed cost estimates and a financing plan are shown in Appendix 3. The Government 
has been informed that approval of the PPTA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing 
project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  Ministry  of  Energy  and  Mines  (MEM)  will  be  the  Executing  Agency,  and  the 
Department  of  Energy  Promotion  and  Development  (DEPD),  the  Department  of  Electricity 
(DOE), and EdL will jointly be the implementing agencies. EGAT has agreed to work closely 
with the consultants on the PPTA’s technical aspects as EGAT is the technical advisor and 
prospective O&M contractor for the common transmission facility. 
 
16.  A steering committee chaired by the director general of DEPD and composed of the 
deputy directors general from DOE and EdL will be established and will review the progress of 
the PPTA on a monthly basis or more frequently if required. 
 
17.  The PPTA will require about 28 person-months of consulting services, including 18 
person-months  of  international  and  10  person-months  of  national  consulting  services.  The 
consulting team will consist of power transmission, financial, economics, legal, environmental, 
and social development specialists. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 4. The 
consultants will submit the following reports to MEM and ADB: 
(i)  an inception report within 1 month after commencement of services; 
(ii)  an interim report 4 months after the commencement of services; 
(iii)  a draft final report 7 months after the commencement of services; and 
(iv)  a final report 8 months after the commencement of services. 
                                                 
4  ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995), and Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998).

5
 
18.  A consulting firm will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). A simplified technical proposal format and 
the  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  (90:10  ratio)  will  be  used.  PPTA-financed 
equipment will be procured under ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time 
to time), and purchased equipment will be handed over to MEM at the end of the services. The 
PPTA will be completed in 8 months, from January 2008 to August 2008. Dissemination of the 
results  will  occur  through  external  press  releases  to  news  agencies,  consultations  with 
nongovernment  organizations,  and  disclosure  on  the  ADB  website.  No  major  risks  are 
associated with the PPTA, and the Government, EGAT, and the hydropower sponsors have 
expressed their strong support. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $760,000 to the Government 
of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic to be financed on a grant basis for preparing the Na 
Bong–Udon Thani Power Transmission Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 2 
INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
Country/Project Title:  Regional Na Bong–Udon Thani Power Transmission Project 
 
Lending/Financing  Multitranche Financing Facility                       Department/  SERD 
Modality:  Division:  SEID 
 
I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
1.  Hydropower is the most abundant natural resource in Lao PDR and represents the country’s single largest 
foreign exchange source, accounting for 30% of total earnings. Therefore, the Government is emphasizing the 
further development of the export-oriented hydropower project and private sector investment to develop similar 
projects.  The  Government  also  recognizes  that  a  factor  contributing  to  poverty  incidence  reduction  is 
improvement in market access internally and with neighboring countries. The Country Strategy Program for Lao 
PDR recognized the importance of developing a hydropower resource as an export commodity to generate 
foreign currency for the Government through royalties, taxes, and dividends on government investment in 
hydropower projects. These projects will contribute to the country’s broader social and economic development 
through an increased revenue base to the Government. The Regional Country Strategy Program (2007–2009) for 
the GMS is based on four pillars, including (i) strengthening physical infrastructure for cross-border connectivity, 
and (ii) integrating national markets for promoting economic efficiency and private sector development. The 
proposed project, which will establish a 500 kV power transmission line between Lao PDR and Thailand and 
support private hydropower investors in Lao PDR, is in line with ADB’s strategy.  
B.  Targeting Classification 
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 General Intervention    Individual or Household (TI-H);  Geographic (TI-G);  Non-Income MDGs (TI-
M1, M2, etc.) 
2.  Explain the basis for the targeting classification: The proposed project is aimed at providing bulk power 
transmission between Thailand and Lao PDR and contributing to Lao PDR’s general economic growth through 
increased revenues to the Government that can used for poverty reduction programs. 
C.  Poverty Analysis 
1.  If the Project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed? Not 
applicable. 
2.  What resources are allocated in the PPTA/due diligence? The PPTA will undertake due diligence on those 
directly affected by the proposed project to ensure that ADB’s safeguard policies are fully complied with.  
3.  If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross subsidy, pro-
poor governance, and pro-poor growth)? There is no opportunity for pro-poor design as the proposed project 
does not have direct beneficiaries other than the Government of Lao PDR through royalties, taxes, and 
dividends.  
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the Project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit 
from the Project? The proposed project’s primary beneficiaries are the Government of Lao PDR and the four 
private sector hydropower developers that will be using the transmission line to transmit power to Thailand. Lao 
PDR’s general and poor population will indirectly benefit through poverty reduction programs to be financed 
through the Government’s additional revenues from hydropower exports to Thailand. In addition, the Nam Ngiep 
I project is supplying 18 MW to the domestic grid, enabling the Government to extend its electrification to rural 
areas. 
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? Not applicable.  
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project 
address them? Not applicable.

Appendix 2  9 
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1.  Indicate the potential initial stakeholders. 
The stakeholders include the private sector hydropower developers that will use the common transmission 
facility; commercial financers to the hydropower projects; government entities such as Ministry of Finance, 
MEM, and EdL; EGAT; the population affected by the Project due to land acquisition; and the civil society and 
nongovernment organizations interested in hydropower development in Lao PDR.  
2.  What type of consultation and participation (C&P) is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g., 
workshops, community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based 
organizations, etc.)? Extensive consultation will be undertaken with the parties that have a commercial interest 
in the proposed project, including private sector investors. IEE findings will be made available to the interested 
parties. Consultation will be undertaken with people directly affected by the proposed project with respect to 
land acquisition and resettlement.  
3.  What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
     Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision-making         Empowerment 
4.  Will a C&P plan be prepared?    Yes          No    Please explain. The consultation process will be included 
in the resettlement plan.   
 
C.  Gender and Development 
1.  What are the key gender issues in the sector/subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project/program? 
The gender issues are related to the resettlement impacts and will be addressed through mainstreaming the 
gender strategy in the resettlement plan.  
 
2.  Does  the  proposed  project/program  have  the  potential  to  promote  gender  equality  and/or  women’s 
empowerment by improving women’s access to and use of opportunities, services, resources, assets, and 
participation in decision making?       Yes          No.    No gender component is required in the project 
design. However, gender equality must be secured during project implementation, when hiring construction 
laborers.  
 
3.  Could the proposed project have an adverse impact on women and/or girls or to widen gender inequality? 
          Yes         No    The proposed project will have positive impacts on women by providing cheaper and 
additional electric supply in Thailand and additional sources of revenue to Lao PDR that can be redistributed 
to widen gender equality.

IV.  PPTA/DUE DILIGENCE RESOURCE REQUIREMENT 
1.  Do the TOR for the PPTA (or other due diligence) include poverty, social and gender analysis and the relevant 
specialist/s?  
        Yes                    No   If no, please explain why.

gender analysis, and C&P during the PPTA/due diligence?       Yes           No    If no, please explain why. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, EdL = Electricité du Laos, EGAT = Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand, 
GMS = Greater Mekong Subregion, IEE = initial environmental examination, kV = kilovolt, Lao PDR = Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic, MEM = Ministry of Energy and Mines, MW = megawatt, PPTA = project preparatory technical 
assistance

Appendix 3  11 
 
COST ESTIMATES AND FINANCING PLAN 
($'000) 
 
  Total 
Item  Cost 
A.  Asian Development Bank Financinga   
  1.  Consultants   
    a.  Remuneration and Per Diem   
      i.  International Consultants  430.00 
      ii.  National Consultants  40.00 
    b.  International and Local Travel  75.00 
    c.  Vehicle Rental  30.00 
    d.  Reports and Communications  10.00 
  2.  Equipment and Softwareb  10.00 
  3.  Miscellaneous Administration and   10.00 
    Support Costs 
  4.  Representative for Contract Negotiations  5.00 
  5.  Contingencies  150.00 
      Subtotal (A)  760.00 
   
B.  Government Financingc   
  1.  Office Accommodationd   35.00 
  2.  Transporte  50.00 
  2.  Remuneration and Per Diem of Counterpart Staff  50.00 
  3.  Others  15.00 
      Subtotal (B)  150.00 
        Total  910.00 
a  Financed by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. 
b  The equipment will be purchased by the consultant and will become the property of the 
Ministry of Energy and Mines at the conclusion of the technical assistance. Equipment to be 
procured will include computers (one desktop and one laptop) with standard office software, 
one printer, and one photocopy machine.  
c  In-kind contribution. 
d  Includes installation of two telephone lines, two high-speed connections, air conditioner, 
electricity and water charges, and office rental fee. The telephone and internet user charges 
will be paid through the consultant fee. 
e  Includes local and air transportation of the counterpart staff. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

12  Appendix 4 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Work 
 
1.  A  consulting  firm  will  be  engaged  to  provide  technical  services  for  a  total  of  28  
person-months of consulting services (18 person-months of international consulting inputs and 
10  person-months  of  domestic  consulting  inputs).  The  consultants  will  report  to  the  Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB).  
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
1.  Power Transmission Specialist/Team Leader (7 person-months) 
 
2.  As  team  leader,  the  consultant  will  be  responsible  for  (i)  coordinating  the  team’s 
activities, and assuring the quality of all project deliverables; (ii) coordinating and preparing all 
reports submitted to the Ministry of Energy and Mines (MEM) and ADB; and (iii) organizing 
training and capacity-building activities. As power transmission specialist, the consultant will 
undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Review the technical design, implementation schedule, and cost estimates of the 
Na Bong–Thailand border 500 kilovolt (kV) transmission line. During the technical 
review of the transmission line, the consultant will assess the technical losses of 
the line to be compared with the actual losses after the said transmission line’s 
commission. 
(ii)  Review  the  seasonal  variation  effects  of  the  four  hydropower  projects,  and 
assess  the  common  transmission  facility’s  load  factor,  both  in  high  and  low 
hydrology,  during  peak  and  off-peak  periods  while  conducting  financial  and 
economic analysis. 
(iii)  Review  the  transmission  line’s  procurement  procedures,  and  carry  out  due 
diligence on transparency and fair selection of the transmission line contractor. 
(iv)  Carry  out  an  independent  assessment  of  the  transmission  line’s  cost,  and 
compare it with the actual cost provided by the Nam Ngum 2 developer. 
(v)  Review  the  500/230  kV  Na  Bong  substation’s  technical  design  during  the 
proposed project’s various phases, i.e., evacuation of power from Nam Ngum 2 
only, with Nam Ngum 3, with Nam Theun 1, and with the fourth and last Nam 
Ngiep  1  hydropower  plant,  and  ensure  that  the  reliability  criteria  of  the 
transmission  system  matches  the  provisions  set  in  various  power  purchase 
agreements (PPAs). 
(vi)  Based  on  (ii)  above,  determine  the  least  cost  investment  for  the  common 
transmission facility, taking into account the optimal technical design, schedule 
for timely completion of the transmission line and substation to evacuate power 
from the associated hydropower projects consistent with their commissioning 
schedule, and the expected availability of the common transmission system. 
(vii)  Review the Lao People’s Democratic Republic’s (Lao PDR) power expansion 
plan and the potential for further hydropower development projects that are likely 
to be connected to the Na Bong substation, and that all necessary spare bays 
are included in the substation’s technical design. Provide information on potential 
for hydropower and mix of generation for the next 5 years.

Appendix 4  13 
(viii)  Review the control system and the telecommunication and metering standards 
that  ensure  full  compatibility  with  the  operating  requirements  of  Electricity 
Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT) and Electricité du Laos (EdL). 
(ix)  With  the  economist  and  financial  experts,  assess  and  recommend  the 
remuneration  of  the  transmission  services,  e.g.,  wheeling  charges;  the 
methodology  for  allocating  wheeling  charges  among  the  four  hydropower 
projects  that  takes  into  account  the  construction  costs,  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) costs, financing cost including interest during construction, 
and other financial charges; and the timing of hydropower projects’ commercial 
operation.  
(x)  Review the prequalification and bidding documents prepared by EGAT for the Na 
Bong substation’s procurement, and ensure that the overall procurement process 
will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time).  
(xi)  Work  with  the  EdL/EGAT  procurement  team  during  the  pre-bid  meeting, 
evaluation of bids, drafting of bid evaluation report, and contract negotiations with 
the successful bidder. 
(xii)  With the legal expert, define the optimal structure of the O&M joint venture 
structure, position job description, and remuneration of the joint venture. 
(xiii)  Assess  the  carbon  dioxide  emissions  reduction  attributable  to  the  proposed 
project and update the country-specific emission factor for Thailand. 
2.  Economist (1 person-month) 
3.  The consultant will undertake, but will not be limited to, the following tasks. 
(i)  Assess the economic benefits individually for Lao PDR and Thailand and at the 
subregional level due to power trading, and identify the rationale for government 
investment in the common transmission facility in accordance with the relevant 
ADB guidelines and methodology.  
(ii)  Identify the risks, and undertake appropriate risk and sensitivity analysis with 
respect  to  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic Analysis 
of Projects (2001). 
(iii)  Identify stakeholders, and conduct a distributional analysis of the net project 
benefits  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Handbook  for  Integrating  Poverty  Impact 
Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects (2001).  
(iv)  With other team members, prepare a project framework that clearly identifies the 
proposed project’s impact, outcome, output and activities, targets or benchmarks, 
monitoring mechanisms, assumptions and potential risks in accordance with ADB 
standards. 
3.  Financial Analyst (3 person-months) 
4.  The consultant’s activities will be guided by, and outputs prepared in accordance with, 
ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005). The consultant will undertake, 
but not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  Review the overall financial viability of the four hydropower projects that will use 
the common transmission facility.

14  Appendix 4 
 
(ii)  Assess the financial benefits to Lao PDR and Thailand due to power trading, and 
identify the rationale for the Government of Lao PDR to invest in the common 
transmission  facility  in  accordance  with  the  relevant  ADB  guidelines  and 
methodology. 
(iii)  Carry  out  in-depth  financial  analysis  of  the  proposed  investment,  including 
calculation of the financial internal rate of return and weighted average cost of 
capital, taking into account all the financial costs and revenues that can be 
attributed to the proposed project. 
(iv)  With the transmission specialist, assess the remuneration of the transmission 
services,  e.g.,  wheeling  charges,  that  will  ensure  cost  recovery,  reasonable 
return to EdL, plus reasonable fees for the O&M joint venture. 
(v)  Identify  all  risks  to  the  proposed  project’s  revenue  and  costs,  and  conduct 
relevant sensitivity analyses on its financial rate of return. 
(vi)  Prepare a detailed project cost estimates table for the proposed investment, 
taking into account all relevant financial costs that include physical and price 
contingencies, interest during construction, commitment fees, and up-front fees. 
(vii)  Prepare a financing plan for the proposed project that includes proposed ADB 
lending, prospective cofinancing, if any, and appropriate counterpart funds for 
local currency expenditures, with price and physical contingencies and interest 
during construction. 
(viii)  Update  financial  projections  for  EdL  for  the  next  10  years  Propose  prudent 
financial covenants to ensure that EdL generates adequate cash flow to finance 
new investments and to repay its loans. 
(ix)  Conduct  in-depth  financial  management  analysis  of  the  proposed  O&M  joint 
venture,  which  includes  its  financial  management  capabilities,  organizational 
structure, and projected financial statements analysis with detailed assumptions. 
4.  Legal Expert (4 person-months) 
5.  The consultant will undertake, but not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  Undertake due diligence on the contractual and/or legal aspects with regard to 
financing of the transmission line by the Nam Ngum 2 developer and transfer of 
its ownership to EdL, including preparation of the legal documentation for the 
transfer. 
(ii)  Undertake due diligence on additional commercial risks borne by EdL due to 
ownership of the transmission line with respect to the hydropower companies’ 
PPA contractual obligations, and propose suitable mechanisms to mitigate these 
risks. 
(iii)  Based on the above, recommend institutional arrangements for the ownership of 
and O&M agreements for the common transmission facility. 
(iv)  Assess the proposed joint venture between EdL and EGAT to undertake the 
common transmission facility’s O&M activities in terms of guarantees, cost, risks, 
and liability for the four developers. Compare and evaluate the advantages of 
such an arrangement with other institutional and contractual arrangements, e.g., 
a  management  contract  or  lease  of  these  assets  during  the  period  of  the 
hydropower projects’ concession agreements. 
(v)  Depending on the above, assist EdL in setting up the O&M joint venture with 
EGAT, and determine the O&M company’s responsibilities in accordance with

Appendix 4  15 
Lao PDR’s current legal framework. Prepare any amendment(s) of the existing 
laws and decrees as deemed necessary. 
(vi)  Develop the joint venture’s operating agreement with respect to reliability criteria, 
pricing and remuneration, litigation and recourse, force majeure, arbitration, etc. 
(vii)  In case of another O&M activities arrangement as mentioned in (iv), determine 
the contractor’s mode of remuneration and the performance criteria.  
(viii)  Prepare  legal  documentation  for  the  payment  of  wheeling  charges  by  the 
hydropower developers to EdL and to the O&M Company, which is consistent 
with the PPA and concession agreements. 
(ix)  Propose contractual and/or legal mechanisms for ring-fencing wheeling charges 
to have the first priority for debt service, including the establishment of an escrow 
account. 
(x)  Determine and negotiate the limit of property and operational responsibility of the 
transmission facilities, i.e., between the 230 kV transmission facilities owned by 
the hydropower companies and the Na Bong 500/230kV substation owned by 
EdL, with the hydropower companies. 
5.  Environmental Specialist (1 person-month international and 5 person-months 
national) 
(i)  Conduct due diligence on Nam Ngum 3 and Nam Ngiep 1 projects on the related 
generation and upstream transmission facilities. Due diligence on Nam Theun 1 
will also be conducted when the proposed project’s impacts are known and the 
documentation is available. 
(ii)  Prepare the initial environmental examination (IEE) for the proposed project’s 
substation component. 
(iii)  Prepare  an  environmental  management  plan  for  the  proposed  project  that 
includes  specific  budget  and  institutional  arrangements  to  implement  the 
mitigation measures and monitoring plan. 
(iv)  Recommend  appropriate  environmental  mitigation  measures  for  identified 
significant impacts, and recommend monitoring plans to address these impacts. 
(v)  Ensure  that  the  cost  of  implementing  mitigation  measures,  environmental 
management  and  monitoring  plans,  and  any  strengthening  measures  are 
included in the proposed project’s cost. 
(vi)  Prepare  the  proposed  project’s  performance  and  monitoring  and  evaluation 
arrangements, including adequate time-bound indicators and relevant baseline 
data,  for  monitoring  and  evaluating  the  implementation  of  recommendations 
under the summary IEE. 
(vii)  In accordance with ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003), review, 
update and revise the IEE prepared by the Nam Ngum 2 developer for the 
transmission line component.  
(viii)  Conduct due diligence on IEE prepared by EGAT on the Thailand portion of the 
transmission  line,  and  ensure  that  it  complies  with  the  requirements  of  the 
Government of Thailand.  
6.  Social Specialist (2 person-months international and 5 person-months national) 
(i)  Prepare a sample-based social impact assessment of the proposed project to 
provide  adequate  information,  including  any  potential  impacts  on  ethnic

16  Appendix 4 
 
minorities; provide mitigation measures/affirmative activities to ensure that ethnic 
minorities are safeguarded during construction and the project implementation 
period;  and  if  necessary,  prepare  an  ethnic  minority-specific  action  plan  for 
inclusion in the resettlement plan in accordance with ADB’s Policy on Indigenous 
Peoples (1998). 
(ii)  Conduct due diligence on the resettlement plan for the transmission line as well 
as  its  implementation;  identify  inconsistencies  with  national  and  ADB  social 
safeguard requirements; recommend solutions or action plans to address these 
irregularities; and summarize the results in the social impact assessment report. 
For the transmission line’s Thailand portion, conduct due diligence on social 
safeguards, and ensure that social impact and mitigation measures are compliant 
with the policy requirements of the Government of Thailand. 
(iii)  Conduct due diligence on Nam Ngum 3 and Nam Ngiep 1 projects on the related 
generation and upstream transmission facilities. Due diligence on Nam Theun 1 
will also be conducted when the proposed project’s impacts are known and the 
documentation is available. 
(iv)  Prepare a resettlement plan for the substation if it results in social impacts that 
will trigger ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). 
(v)  Review  and  assess  the  risk  of  spreading  HIV/AIDS  and  other  sexually 
transmitted diseases during the construction phase. Review the HIV/AIDS and 
sexually transmitted disease awareness program and its implementation by the 
contractors, and propose measures to improve them. 
(vi)  Review and ensure that suitable and acceptable consultations have occurred and 
that  the  project  resettlement  plans  and  ethnic  minority-specific  action  or 
development  plans,  if  any,  have  been  disclosed  to  affected  people,  that  an 
adequate  independent  external  monitoring  and  evaluation  entity  has  been 
recruited under the proposed project.  
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
6.  MEM will act as the Executing Agency, and the Department of Energy Promotion and 
Development  (DEPD),  Department  of  Energy  (DOE),  and  EdL  will  jointly  act  as  the 
implementing agencies for the PPTA. DEPD/EdL will provide counterpart staff, office space, and 
office furniture without cost to the consultants. 
D.  Reporting 
7.  The consultants will prepare the following reports for MEM and ADB: (i) an inception 
report within 1 month after the commencement of services; (ii) an interim report 4 months after 
the commencement of services; (iii) a draft final report 7 months after the commencement of 
services; and (iv) a final report 8 months after the commencement of services. In addition to 
these mandatory reports, the consultants will prepare specific reports as stated in the terms of 
reference, such as a report on the review of the bidding documents and bidding process and a 
bid evaluation report.  
8.  Tripartite meetings will be held in Vientiane after submission of the inception, interim, 
and draft final reports.

ABBREVIATIONS

  DEPD  –  Department of Energy Promotion and Development 
  DOE  –  Department of Energy 
  EdL  –  Electricité du Laos 
  EGAT  –  Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand

  IEE  –  initial environmental examination 
  kV  –  kilovolt 
  Lao PDR  –  Lao People’s Democratic Republic

  MFF  –  multitranche financing facility 
  MW  –  megawatt 
  O&M  –  operation and maintenance 
  PPA  –  power purchase agreement 
  PPTA  –  project preparatory technical assistance 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Energy 
Subsector  –  Transmission and distribution 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth; regional cooperation  
Subthemes  –  Fostering physical infrastructure development; cross-
border infrastructure 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.
